title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 11
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: "Impossible to deny a kind of decency to this Catriona, andsense forbye! As for James More, the man's as boss as a drum; he's justa wame and a wheen words; though I'll can never deny that he foughtreasonably well at Gladsmuir, and it's true what he says here about thefive wounds.

title: Hill-side and border sketches:

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Home and I stopped at Polwarth manse for a night, and Eobertson and Adam went on by Longformacus to Gladsmuir, Robertson's abode.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: bought a £20 horse, and the rest of us what trinkets we thought we wanted— Robertson for his wife and children at Gladsmuir, and Home and I for the children  at Polwarth manse.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Not so Robertson Avith the Arniston family, who had got him the church of Gladsmuir.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Hew Bannatine | had been ordained minister of Ormiston, who was a ; first-rate man for sound understandino; and classical i learning; Eobertson was at Gladsmuir; and in January  1747 John Home was settled at Athelstaneford ; so that I had neighbours and companions of the first rank in point of mind and erudition.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Robertson mounted his horse, and left us to go round by his house at Gladsmuir to get a little money, as he had not wherewithal to defray his expenses, and mentioned an hour when he promised  to meet us at Bangley Braefoot, Maggie Johnstone' s, a public-house on the road leading to Dunbar, by Garlton Hills, a mile to the north of Haddington.

title: Romance of War ... New edition
author: Grant, James
snippet: Their comrades were all defeated, themselveswere threatened by cavalry, galled by ten pieces of cannon, and opposedto three thousand infantry ; and yet they went on with the heedless impetuosity of the heroes of Killiecrankie, Falkirk, and Gladsmuir.
